Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Diversity and Innovation for Geosciences in Texas (DIG TEXAS) - an Alliance for Earth Science Literacy
Award.AbstractNarration: DIG TEXAS (Diversity and Innovation for Geosciences in Texas) is an alliance comprising earth scientists, educators and other stakeholders with a shared vision to elevate the stature of the geosciences in Texas. With funding from NSF's Geoscience Education program, DIG TEXAS is using cybertechnology to promote collaboration among alliance members and support activities designed to strengthen earth science education in Texas. The project is creating five on-line course road maps, or blueprints, for use in high school earth science classes. Each blueprint consists of an original scope and sequence, packaged with links to pre-existing, exemplary learning activities and resources. Regional teams are working to tailor the blueprints so that they address the specific needs of the diverse student population and educators who work with them throughout the state. The Science Education Resource Center (SERC) at Carleton College serves as the repository for the blueprint web pages, which also is accessible from the DIG TEXAS website. CYBER-ShARE, a Center of Excellence at the University of Texas at El Paso, is collaborating with SERC to create structural frameworks for organizing information in the collections. Coherent blueprints for implementation of a 21st century earth science course are lacking, not only in Texas, but also throughout the nation in general. Therefore the blueprints are also expected to serve as examples of earth science instruction in other states by demonstrating the integration of stellar teaching resources into earth science courses.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project seeks to map the best available online Earth science teaching resources and curricula with high school standards that will serve a large audience in Texas. The broader impacts of this project rest in very wide applicability, use and ease of free access provided to teachers across the state to these curated and vetted resources. The intellectual merit of this project rests in the technique for building regionally-focused teams of teachers and university educators and experts and the framework for taking existing resources and repackaging them with state-specific educational outcomes for broad use with little additional expense. 

The project has achieved this goal through the curation of geoscience educational resources organized within the framework of five DIG-Texas (Diversity and Innovation in Geoscience -Texas) Instructional Blueprints. A single blueprint comprises three­week units for teachers to use to teach a year-long Earth science course or a condensed summer course. Each unit addresses the new NGSS, ensuring that the blueprints will have application beyond Texas. The impact on secondary Earth science education in Texas may be extensive as Earth science is not currently taught regularly or in an impactful way evenly across the state – this project may remedy that in a powerful and lasting way.

The impact on project participants is significant. Evaluation results reveal that participants have benefitted by working collaboratively with team members who have diverse educational backgrounds. This is strength of the project. Participants have become proficient at using a resource review tool created by SERC to vet educational resources and SERC’s CMS to organize selected educational resources into instructional units. They have learned to recognize quality educational materials from credible sources and have thus become more discerning users of Earth science educational resources. All project participants are highly interested in and committed to the DIG-Texas project and its goals.

The projected impacts on geosciences involve inclusion of and links to material from supporting disciplines. This has been taken into consideration in the work done to date by regional teams and implementation during a pilot rollout in 2014­ 2015.?In addition, the cross­disciplinary teams include both Earth science and education faculty members. Project participants who are experts in curriculum and instruction, science education, and technology education are developing knowledge in Earth science and learning about the specific challenges and opportunities associated with Earth science education. They brought this new knowledge and the Earth science instructional blueprints developed through this project to bear on their teaching and research activities.

The classroom-ready resources resulting from this project are publicly available at http://serc.carleton.edu/dig_blueprints/index.html
